text: hi hi hi everyone anthony fantano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new amber
mark album three dimensions deep this is
the debut full-length lp of singer
songwriter and producer miss amber mark
who has been grinding for years now with
singles and ep and mini album features
but she uh finally ended up catching my
attention and the attention of many with
some of the singles leading up to this
new full-length album what it is and
foreign things these really big
luxurious fusions of r b and pop which
were impeccably groovy catchy and sweet
bold lead vocals too which are certainly
a breath of fresh air from the very
washed out aesthetics and sounds that
have kind of dominated r b at large for
the past decade not to imply amber is
the antithesis to anything or that she
stands in opposition to anyone's sound
style or trend with her music because
the singles on this record were really
just a taste of what was to come because
three dimensions deep is a 17 track one
hour experience which ended up being a
pretty well-rounded project that covers
quite a few bases with numerous strains
and eras of pop r b and soul being
reflected in its track list along with
some detours into a latin pop and dance
hall how much amber is offering off the
bat here is pretty impressive in itself
but there are still spots where it feels
like three dimensions deep is stretching
itself a little thin with amber working
through some sounds here and there that
hit a little awkwardly or just don't
leave as much of a mark as others
healing hertz for example is one of the
most heartfelt and beautiful ballads on
the entire record with a soaring and
impassioned vocal performance from amber
that's absolutely killer but the meat
and potatoes backing trap beat
kind of serving as the backbone for the
whole thing just feels so at odds with
the elegant strings and vocal work amber
also hops into a more latin inspired
sound on the song softly which i feel
like she falls into the same trap many
artisan majors do when they are
addressing this sound trying to put a
super low key super understated maybe
even sleepy spin on it which just ends
up sounding really vague and completely
cutting out all of the fun and
exuberance this style of music has to
offer there are so many lush
arrangements as well on the song on and
on but it feels like kind of a waste to
have much of them just layering on top
of each other and syncing up with the
kicks of the track the pacing and groove
gets a little tedious by the time the
strings get a bit more ambitious this
song leads into a kind of reverb heavy
alt r b pocket of the record leading to
the track out of this world which does
have its moments it certainly achieves
an intergalactic sound with all of these
nods toward stars and planets and a love
that just feels otherworldly but the
track doesn't really provide a strong
finish it fizzles out in the end and
ends up feeling like a sort of long
interlude and oddly the song darkseid's
cluttered production kind of buried
vocals feel like they are pulling from a
supremely nostalgic place the big beats
and rushes of instrumentation feel like
amber is trying to recreate uh the
sensation of listening to an old janet
record or something like off a boombox
or something from that era i like the
tune of the track and when i squint at
it i can kind of see what it's going for
but
sonically i don't think it's quite there
though i do admire the grand finale of
the song so look i do have my
reservations with these tracks but they
really only end up being a fraction of
this very large track list which is
loaded with great cuts what it is and
foreign things are still huge
hard-hitting exuberant and fun singles
within the track list of the record
after multiple listens still can't get
enough of them the song one is a really
strong opener that pulls on fat hip-hop
beats and classic soul chops with
angelic vocals from amber that show her
musing about being stressed and
wondering about whether or not she has
what it takes to succeed in the music
world while being true to herself most
men is another great vocal performance
solid tune some impressive chord changes
on the back end too with a lot of
inspiring lyrics from amber about just
moving on from a relationship where you
felt used plus some of those hook vocals
you gotta cut that player out like the
finesse the song fomo skips across a
peppy danceable beat and if it wasn't
already clear from the title it's a
track essentially about being content in
your own growth pursuits struggles
what-have-you while not investing too
much time or worry in the seemingly
ideal lives that you may see friends or
other people living through social media
feeds something like that it's a track
that dares to be both substantive and
catchy while showcasing a pretty sharp
rap verse from amber on the back end if
there was any doubt that she's not like
the total package the song cosmic
instrumentally leads in a spacier
direction but that space is complemented
with one of the stronger vocal
performances on the entire lp poetically
amber does a great job of encapsulating
that otherworldly feeling of love too
mentioning it feeling also cinematic
with the instrumentation to match even
some gospel style chorus vocals on the
back end there's also a pretty strong
final leg on this lp2 i love the song
worth its two-part approach it's a
beautiful and encouraging statement on
loving someone else or yourself really
anybody who has a a tendency to be too
hard on themselves the first half of the
tracks great very solid the song could
have easily just been this but then it's
even more gratifying after a great beat
switch around the midpoint it's just
like an amazing gift i didn't see coming
competition is another inspirational cut
too about sharing in one's wealth or
success rejecting a greedy or
self-centered mindset it's simply saying
life doesn't need to be a competition
whether that be in the world of music or
love then finally the song bliss is a
very happy note for this record to end
on certainly contrasts the very unsure
and uneasy feelings this album kicks off
with the groove of this track rides on a
really lazy and sweet funk beaten bass
line and all in all one more example of
amber's very great and very sharp
songwriting chops like she absolutely
knows her way around a chorus now this
isn't the final final track of the
record that would be event horizon which
is sort of like a very
starry and lullaby-esque afterthought
for the lp kind of feels like a bridge
into a dream or whatever the next phase
of her music career will be and overall
while i did think there was some fat to
be trimmed in the track list here some
tracks that could have been sharpened i
think this is a relatively lovely debut
there are a lot of cuts here that
showcase amber's talents and certainly
prove her to be an artist to look out
for into the future she's got a great
voice thoughtful lyrics and clearly has
studied enough
in the genres that she operates into
pull from their past effectively and
does it without getting overly nostalgic
much of the time from here i can only
hope the ambition that drove her to make
such a large and thematic project leads
her to bigger and bolder places in the
future i'm feeling a strong six to a
light seven here tran position have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
amber mark
forever
